ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Important skills regarding research practices, structuring research papers and communicating with faculty members.

Learning how to formulate and write a research paper about a political leader/ idea that interests you. 

What does a prospectus look like, how do you pace your writing. 

Readings every week on political science theory to help ideas for paper and  learn about leadership generally.
I learned the skill of writing a very long research paper. Also learned the core tenets of political leadership and the scholarship behind it.

I greatly developed an understanding of what shapes the political moments in which leaders act. As my first class in political science, this course was a jump start in the polisci way of thinking for the social sciences. The type of analysis was unlike I had ever seen and was as challenging as it was enriching. I also learned to conduct long-term research and I practiced my ability to make subtle points about historical situations.

I think the workshop part of this course was great, and I really appreciated the direct feedback the professor gives. I think a lot of people feel awkward about giving direct and honest feedback, and I think it hurts writing development in many classes, but not this one. The readings for each week were very interesting, and I think the critical debates were very helpful.
I gained the ability to write and learn about the various topics covered about how leaders think and make decisions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Grade transparency throughout the semester
Prof Skowronek is an amazing professor. He is very knowledgeable and makes the workshop format of the class accessible to everyone and enjoyable.

The workshop worked for developing the papers over the course of the semester. There could have been more class discussion about the readings rather than what seemed at times like a lecture. People were eager to engage with the course material.

The material is very well chosen, and the professor knows it very well. The lecture part of the class is always tremendously insightful, and I found the discussion to be engaging. The class does due diligence in providing an introduction to political leadership, but it might as well be an American presidency class. As an international student, I learned a lot about American presidential history, and I acknowledge that Prof. Skowroneks expertise is in that subject, but I wish we would have done as deep of a dive in other important leaders, particularly those of non-western countries. In terms of the writing part, the investigation is completely independent and there is no hand-holding whatsoever. There was never a rubric and the commentary that the professor did was sharp and insightful but limited, and can only be understood with a clear mind about the subject. If you are not confident in the subject, which few people ever were, there is little help to get you out of that gutter. The writing is also basically completely independent of the reading, which is okay, but different than other writing courses where they are more intertwined.

Strengths: workshop structure, professor's feedback, 
Weaknesses: reading selection felt a little too abstract and hard to apply to the paper

The strengths of this course are that it allows the student to truly think at a deeper level and communicate thoughts to other classmates, however, it could be improved by being more organized and having more engaging class sessions.
Lectures could be more focused on material that would help us in writing papers

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Unless they plan to do it for their senior paper, absolutely not.
Yes, if you want to improve your without g this class is the one for you.
Yes

Yes, if you are able to handle the heat. The intellectual challenge and workload of this course are manageable but very consuming. The courses overarching theme and main takeaways are the subject of a 200-level course, but sometimes the discussion, writing feedback, and general independence feels like a senior seminar would. Do not rely on the professor to help you untangle the paper, only to inspect the argument.
The topics are interesting, but if they're interested in writing their paper, the discussion is not good, so don't take it.
Yes. I think the workshop structure is very helpful, and the class discussions are very interesting.
I would recommend this course to a student who wants to better their writing skills and have intellectual conversations with like-minded students.
Yes, paper writing process helped me developed numerous skills
